title: UN Security Council Expands to Include India, Brazil, and Germany
introText: The United Nations has approved the most significant reform in its 80-year history, expanding the Security Council to include India, Brazil, and Germany as permanent members. The expansion aims to better reflect 21st-century global power dynamics.

content.content: UN Security Council undergoes historic expansion

The UN General Assembly voted 178-12 to amend the Charter, adding three permanent seats to the Security Council for the first time since 1965. India, Brazil, and Germany will join the US, UK, France, Russia, and China as permanent members.
The reform follows decades of negotiations. UN Secretary-General called it 'a new chapter for multilateralism,' arguing the body's composition must reflect current global realities.

The compromise grants new members a modified veto â€“ they can block resolutions only when joined by at least one other permanent member. This addresses concerns about expanding unilateral veto power while giving new members meaningful influence.
Existing permanent members retain full veto rights. Russia and China initially opposed expansion but ultimately agreed following assurances about regional balance.
India brings over 1.4 billion people into permanent representation, addressing longstanding complaints about democratic deficit. Brazil represents Latin America on the body for the first time.
African nations pushed for continental representation and secured commitment for a future African permanent seat within five years, with details to be negotiated.
The expanded Council will address challenges from climate change to emerging technologies. Proponents hope broader membership will reduce gridlock and increase the legitimacy of UN decisions.

summary: UN Security Council adds India, Brazil, and Germany as permanent members with limited vetoes, promising an African seat within five years.
